abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: This chapter provides an overview of the factors that influence Earth’s climate. The relation between reconstructions of global mean surface temperature and estimates of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) over the past 500 million years is first described. Vast variations in climate on geologic time scales, driven by natural fluctuations of CO2, are readily apparent. We then shift attention to the time period 1765 to present, known as the Anthropocene, during which human activity has strongly influenced atmospheric CO2, other greenhouse gases (GHGs), and Earth’s climate. Two mathematical concepts essential for quantitative understanding of climate change, radiative forcing and global warming potential, are described. Next, fingerprints of the impact of human activity on rising temperature and the abundance of various GHGs over the course of the Anthropocene are presented. We conclude by showing Earth is in the midst of a remarkable transformation. In the past, radiative forcing of climate represented a balance between warming due to rising GHGs and cooling due to the presence of suspended particles (aerosols) in the troposphere. There presently exists considerable uncertainty in the actual magnitude of radiative forcing of climate due to tropospheric aerosols, which has important consequences for our understanding of the climate system. In the future, climate will be driven mainly by GHG warming because aerosol precursors are being effectively removed from pollution sources, due to air quality legislation enacted in response to public health concerns.

sec.title: Earth’s Climate History
sec.p: Reconstructions of Earth’s climate provide a remarkable record of environmental change over vast periods of time. The co-evolution of climate and life on Earth is well established (Schneider 1984; Kasting and Siefert 2002; Sagan and Mullen 1972; Petit et al. 1999). Earth’s paleoclimate record is examined here, in some detail, because knowledge of the past is key to understanding the future.

The earliest evidence for life on Earth dates to about 3.5 billion years before present (Bybp) (Brasier et al. 2002). Early life consisted of prokaryotesprokaryotes, one celled bacteria that thrived in an oxygen (O2) free environment. These organisms had no nucleus and reproduced by cell division. The first prokaryotes likely made organic matter by combining carbon dioxide (CO2carbon dioxide) with molecules such as hydrogen sulfide (H2S), releasing water (H2Owater) and elemental sulfur to the environment (Canfield and Raiswell 1999).

Early in Earth’s history the favored atmospheric fate for carbon-bearing compounds was methane (CH4methane), because the atmosphere was in a state chemists call “reducing”. Stellar astronomy indicates that at the time early life formed, the luminosity of our Sun was about 30 % less than today, which should have caused ancient oceans to freeze. As explored in detail throughout this book, CH4methane is a more potent greenhouse gas (GHGGreenhouse gas) than CO2carbon dioxide. Extremely high levels of atmospheric CH4methane and ammonia (NH3), another reduced compound that is also a strong GHGGreenhouse gas, were likely responsible for preventing Earth’s ancient oceans from freezing (Sagan and Mullen 1972).

Prokaryotes were the first to develop photosynthesisphotosynthesis, the ability to convert sunlight, carbon dioxide (CO2carbon dioxide), and water (H2Owater) into glucose C6H12O6. Eventually, prokaryotic photosynthesis caused atmospheric O2 to rise from about one part per million of all air molecules to 21 %. Margulis and Sagan (1986) call the initial build-up of atmospheric O2 the greatest environmental crisis Earth has ever endured. At the time, O2 was toxic to most life on Earth. As a result, a mass extinction called the Great Oxygenation EventphotosynthesisGreat Oxygenation Event occurred about 2.5 Bybp. One can only imagine the emergency meetings of bacterial communities, seeking to ban their photosynthetic cousins in an effort to halt the build-up of atmospheric O2.

The rise of atmospheric O2 had enormous consequences. For the first time in Earth’s history, CO2carbon dioxide was the favored state for atmospheric carbon gases. Conversion of atmospheric CH4methane to CO2carbon dioxide likely led to Earth’s first glaciationglaciationfirst glaciation event about 2.4 Bybp (Frei et al. 2009). The build-up of O2 also led to formation of Earth’s protective ozone (O3) layerozone layer, which was necessary for life to emerge from sea to land. Finally, the global, atmospheric chemical shock induced by the Great Oxygenation Event facilitated the evolution of eukaryotes: nucleated cells that metabolize O2. You are made of eukaryotic cells!

Plant life first appeared on land about 500 million years before present (Mybp) (Kenrick and Crane 1997). Even though, as alluded to above, much is known about climate and the state of Earth’s atmosphere prior to this time, reconstructions of global variations in Earth’s climate and atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide are only available for the most recent 500 million years.

Figure 1.1 shows the variations in the global mean surface temperatureglobal mean surface temperature and the abundance of carbon dioxide (CO2carbon dioxide) over the past 500 million years. The temperature estimates are anomalies (ΔTGMST anomaly) with respect to the mean state of Earth’s climate that existed during recent pre-industrial timepre-industrial (i.e., years 1850–1900). Notable events regarding the evolution of life (Dinosaurs, Rise of Mammals, etc.) are indicated to the left and phenomenon regarding the global carbon cyclecarbon cycle and climate (Rise of Forests, Greenland Glaciation, etc.) are marked to the right. This figure is our composite of a considerable number of paleoclimatic studies, as described in Methods. To facilitate discussion of this figure, six Eras are denoted. These should not be confused with the formal use of the word Era by Geologists. Each era in Fig. 1.1 spans a different length of time; the interval over which Dinosaurs lived (about 230–65 Mybp) is about 2.5 times longer than the time between the Rise of Mammals and present.Fig. 1.1
Earth’s climate history, past 500 million years. Historical evolution of global mean surface temperatureglobal mean surface temperature anomaly (ΔTGMST anomaly) relative to a pre-industrial baseline (i.e., mean value of global temperate over 1850–1900) (left) and the atmospheric mixing ratio of CO2carbon dioxide (right). Major events in the evolution of life on Earth as well as either changes in climate of the global carbon cyclecarbon cycle are denoted. The vertical line on the ΔTGMST anomaly panel at zero marks the pre-industrial baseline; the vertical lines on the CO2carbon dioxide panel denote mixing ratios of 280 ppm (pre-industrial), 400 ppm (current level) and 560 ppm (twice pre-industrial level). These time series are based on hundreds of studies; see Methods for further information

Figure 1.1 shows that Earth has undergone vast changes in climate as well as the abundance of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide. A logarithmic scale is used to represent the mixing ratio of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide, because the radiative forcingradiative forcing of climate (see Sect. 1.2.1) is proportional to the logarithm of CO2carbon dioxide. Figure 1.1 shows, clearly and beyond debate, the strong association of Earth’s climate and atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide. Looking backwards in time, as CO2carbon dioxide rises, Earth warms.

On geological time scales, atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide is controlled by the carbonate-silicate cyclecarbon cyclecarbonate-silicate cycle (Berner et al. 1983). Atmospheric supply of CO2carbon dioxide occurs during volcanicvolcanic activity eruptions and hydrothermal ventingdeep sea vents. Atmospheric removal of CO2carbon dioxide is more complicated. The weathering of minerals converts atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide into a water soluble form of carbon; ocean organisms incorporate soluble carbon into their shells and, when these animals perish, their shells sink to the ocean floor. Plate tectonicsplate tectonics buries the sinking sediment, after which the carbon either remains in Earth’s mantle or, on occasion, is spewed back to the atmosphere-ocean system, via either volcanoes or deep sea ventsdeep sea vents.

The first dramatic perturbation to the carbonate-silicate cyclecarbon cyclecarbonate-silicate cycle was induced by the rise of forests. About 500 Mybp, atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide may have been as high as 5000 parts per million by volume (ppm), more than a factor of 10 larger than today (Fig. 1.1) (Berner 1997). Of course, Earth was also exceedingly warm compared to today. The first plantsplants to evolve, bryophytes, were algae-like organisms that probably eased the transition from sea to land by finding homes on moist rocky surfaces. Bryophytes are known as non-vascular plants; they lack roots to transport moisture. Moss is a modern-day bryophyte. Vascular pteridophytes (fern-like organisms) evolved about 500 Mybp, soon leading to the rise of forests. This resulted in a steady, dramatic decline in atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide because early forests lacked the abundant bacteria, fungi, and small soil animals that recycle plant matter in contemporary forests. Carbon in the forests that prevailed during the time depicted as Era 6 of Fig. 1.1 was buried and converted to modern day coal and natural gasfossil fuels deposits, due to the intense heat and pressure within Earth’s mantle. This carbon is now being released back to the atmosphere–ocean system, perhaps to generate the electricity used to help you read this book.

The next event that transformed the global carbon cyclecarbon cycle was the rise of the Himalayas (Raymo and Ruddiman 1992). During the period of time depicted in Era 5, plate tectonicsplate tectonics resulted in the formation of the modern-day continents. The exposure of fresh minerals due to the vast tectonic activity associated with formation of the Himalayan mountain range, the largest in the world, led to the steady draw down of CO2carbon cyclecarbonate-silicate cycle and associated cooling depicted in Era 5 of Fig. 1.1.

About 3 Mybp, two remarkable events occurred. Our predecessor Lucy (Australopithecus afarensis) roamed modern day Ethiopia (Johanson and White 1979). At about the same time, Greenland first became glaciatedglaciation (Lunt et al. 2008). While the emergence of an early humanearly humans ancestor who walked in an upright manner is in no way related to the glaciation of Greenland, it is worth noting that global mean surface temperatureglobal mean surface temperature and atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide at the time of Lucy were both estimated to be at modern, pre-industrial levels (Era 4, Fig. 1.1).

The most compelling association of CO2carbon dioxide and climate is provided by the co-variance of these quantities during the past 800,000 years (Era 3, Fig. 1.1) (Imbrie and Imbrie 1979). Earth’s climate oscillated between glaciatedglaciation and inter-glacial states, with atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide levels of about 200 ppm and 280 ppm, respectively, characterizing each state (Barnola et al. 1987). Lower levels of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide prevailed during glacial times due to more productive ocean biogeochemical uptakecarbon cycle (Marino et al. 1992), perhaps facilitated by the oceanic supply of iron resulting from the grinding of glaciers on rock (Martin 1990). The ultimate pace-maker of these cycles is orbital variations of Earth about the Sun, known as MilankovitchMilankovitch cycles cycles (Imbrie and Imbrie 1979).

The precise timing of the rise and fall of temperature and CO2carbon dioxide during Era 3 of Fig. 1.1 is a source of considerable dispute between the climate “believers” and “deniers”. The initial, literal interpretation of the ice coreice cores record suggested that changes in temperature proceeded variations in CO2carbon dioxide by about 800 years (Caillon et al. 2003). If so, the deniers argue, then CO2carbon dioxide is responding to, rather than driving, global climate change. It is essential to appreciate that: the ice coreice cores record of CO2carbon dioxide is discerned by measuring the composition of bubbles trapped in ice; historic temperature is quantified by measuring isotopic composition of the hydrogen and/or oxygen elements within the ice; and bubbles within the sampled ice cores move with respect to the surrounding ice over geologic time. A recent re-analysis of the timing of variations in temperature and CO2carbon dioxide of an Antarctic ice coreice cores, which considers movement of bubbles with respect to the surrounding ice, reveals synchronous variation within the uncertainty of measurement (Parrenin et al. 2013). This interpretation supports the view that changes in atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide did indeed drive glacial/interglacial transitions.

Ancient air preserved in ice coresice cores reveals that when Earth underwent glacial conditions during Era 3 of Fig. 1.1, atmospheric CH4methane fell to about 0.4 ppm. During interglacial periods, atmospheric CH4methane reached a value of 0.7 ppm (Petit et al. 1999; Loulergue et al. 2008). Natural sources of CH4methanesourcesmethane vary by an amount large enough to induce considerable variations in atmospheric abundance, with some consequence for the radiative forcingradiative forcing of climate. Methane is released to the atmosphere when frequently flooded regions (wetlands) experience low oxygen (anaerobic) conditions. It is likely that the higher levels of CH4methane during warm epochs was due to a larger preponderance of wetlands, particularly in the northern hemisphere (NH), as these regions went from ice-covered to ice-free as Earth transitioned from glacial to interglacial conditions (Brook et al. 2000; Sowers 2006). Variations in atmospheric CH4methane also played a role in driving glacial/interglacial climate cycles.

The correlation of temperature and atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide over vast periods of Earth’s history is firmly established by the hundreds of studies that have led to our composite Fig. 1.1. Of course, correlation does not necessarily imply causation. The radiative forcingradiative forcing of climate due to CO2carbon dioxide and other GHGsminor GHGs is explored in great detail later in this chapter.

Modern Homo sapiens evolved about 200,000 years ago and left Africa about 100,000 years ago (Carto et al. 2009). The paths of early humansearly humans were influenced by various rapid climate change events that took place at the end of Era 3 and the start of Era 2 of Fig. 1.1. During the height of most recent glaciationglaciation, about 20,000 years ago, modern day Manhattan was under a sheet of ice nearly half a mile thick and global sea level was 120–130 m (about 400 ft!) lower than today. Human settlement of North America hugged the coastline, as the interior was inhospitable if not impassable. Scandinavia, England, Wales, Scotland, and Ireland were similarly buried under year-long ice.

Modern agricultureagriculture was invented during the Neolithic Revolution, about 12,500 years ago. The Earth was in the midst of climatic warming following the end of the last ice age, which has been implicated as a causal factor because the domestication of plantsplants and animals occurred nearly simultaneously at places separated by great distance (Gepts and Papa 2001). Agricultureagriculture flourished, population grew, and humans colonized all parts of the Earth (except Antarctica) during the climatically quiescent times depicted at the end of Era 2 and start of Era 1 in Fig. 1.1.

Eventually, population rose to an extent that humans began to exert a measurable effect on the GHGGreenhouse gas levels of the atmosphere, a time period now known as the AnthropoceneAnthropocene (Crutzen and Stoermer 2000). Figure 1.2 illustrates the time evolution of ΔTGMST anomaly, CO2carbon dioxide, CH4methane, nitrous oxide (N2Onitrous oxide), and population during the past 2000 years, the so-called Common Era. The association of the rise in population and increased atmospheric levels of CO2carbon dioxide, CH4methane, and N2Onitrous oxide is again irrefutable. Before delving into the Anthropocene, we shall comment on one more controversy.Fig. 1.2
Temperature, GHGs, and population, Common Era. Time series of Earth’s global mean surface temperatureglobal mean surface temperature anomaly (ΔTGMST anomaly) relative to pre-industrial baseline (1850–1900 mean) (Jones and Mann 2004; Jones et al. 2012), the atmospheric mixing ratio of CO2carbon dioxide, CH4methane, and N2Onitrous oxide (MacFarling Meure et al. 2006; Ballantyne et al. 2012; Dlugokencky et al. 2009; Montzka et al. 2011) and global population (Klein Goldewijk et al. 2010; United Nations 2015) over the Common Era. See Methods for further information

Europe experienced unusually warm temperatures from about 950–1250 AD, a time known as the Medieval Warm Period (MWPMedieval Warm Period) (Moberg et al. 2005). Our Fig. 1.2, which relies on the global temperature reconstruction of Jones and Mann (2004), does not depict the MWPMedieval Warm Period. The study of Jones and Mann (2004) suggests the MWPMedieval Warm Period was regional in nature, with little to no global expression. The temperature record in Fig. 1.2, which has become known as “The Hockey Stick”, has led to considerable controversy. One account is described in the book The Hockey Stick and the Climate Wars: Dispatches from the Front Lines (Mann 2012). In 2006, the United States National Academy of Sciences (NAS 2006) reviewed the voluminous literature on climate reconstructions over the Common Era and concluded:
Based on the analyses presented in the original papers by Mann et al. and this newer supporting evidence, the committee finds it plausible that the Northern Hemisphere was warmer during the last few decades of the 20th century than during any comparable period over the preceding millennium. The substantial uncertainties currently present in the quantitative assessment of large-scale surface temperature changes prior to about A.D. 1600 lower our confidence in this conclusion compared to the high level of confidence we place in the Little Ice Age cooling and 20th century warming. Even less confidence can be placed in the original conclusions by Mann et al. (1999) that ‘the 1990s are likely the warmest decade, and 1998 the warmest year, in at least a millennium’ because the uncertainties inherent in temperature reconstructions for individual years and decades are larger than those for longer time periods and because not all of the available proxies record temperature information on such short timescales.

This NAS statement provides fodder for both the believers and deniers. The deniers posit that if global temperature was indeed unusually warm from 950 to 1250 AD, at a time when CO2carbon dioxide, CH4methane, and N2Onitrous oxide were known to be stable (Fig. 1.2), then other factors such as solar luminosity must be responsible. If so, the argument goes, then perhaps the late twentieth century and early twenty-first century warming is due to some factor other than anthropogenic GHGs.

A recent study of ocean heatocean heat content supports the view that the higher temperature of the MWPMedieval Warm Period was indeed global in nature (Rosenthal et al. 2013), similar to the conclusion reached by Soon and Baliunas (2003) a decade earlier. If so, then the time series of ΔTGMST anomaly shown in Fig. 1.2 is in need of revision. Regardless, as shown below, extremely strong scientific evidence implicates GHGs produced by human activities as the primary driver of rising global temperature during the past half-century.

sec.title: The Anthropocene
sec.p: The AnthropoceneAnthropocene refers to the recent interval during which the atmospheric abundance of GHGs that drive Earth’s climate have increased due to human activity (Crutzen and Stoermer 2000). Most peg the start of the Anthropocene to the mid-eighteenth century, linked to the invention of the steam engine by James Watt in 1784 (Steffen et al. 2015). Others suggest humans have had a discernable influence on GHGs for a much longer period of time, and argue for a start date to the Anthropocene as far back as 8000 years before present (ybp) (Ruddiman 2003).

We use 1765 as the start of the AnthropoceneAnthropocene for several reasons. The largest influence of humans on GHGs has certainly occurred since 1765. Estimates of radiative forcingradiative forcing of climate (defined in Sect. 1.2.1) due to a wide variety of human activities based on a multi-year effort of scientists from many nations, are available in a transparent, easily accessible format1 back to 1765 (Meinshausen et al. 2011). Finally, changes in global mean surface temperatureglobal mean surface temperature, to which RF ofradiative forcing climate will be related, are much more certain from 1765 to present than for times extending back to the invention of agricultureagriculture (NAS 2006). Our choice is not meant to dismiss the importance of human influence on climate prior to 1765. If, as suggested by Ruddiman (2003), human activity 8000 ybp did indeed offset the onset of extensive glaciationglaciation due to declining summer insolation at Northern high latitudes (driven by MilankovitchMilankovitch cycles orbital variations), this would be a fascinating benefit of human ingenuity, especially for indigenous peoples of high northerly latitudes.

Rather than wade deeper into the debate over the start of the AnthropoceneAnthropocene, we next describe a few figures that illustrate the human fingerprint on the global carbon cyclecarbon cycle and climate change over the past several centuries. Along the way, the mathematical principles needed to understand the material presented in Chaps. 2 and 3 are developed.

sec.title: Radiative Forcing
sec.p: The greenhouse effectgreenhouse effect, the trapping of radiationradiation by our planet’s atmosphere, is responsible for the difference between the Earth’s actual temperature and that found using Eq. 1.1. Earth’s mean surface temperature is about 15.5 °C or 60 °F. Earth’s atmosphere is responsible for increasing the amount of energy the surface receives, by several hundred W m−2, in comparison to an Earth devoid of an atmosphere. This excess heat is driven by the abundance and molecular properties of GHGs such as H2Owater, CO2carbon dioxide, CH4methane, and N2Onitrous oxide, as well as cloudsclouds (i.e., condensed H2Owater droplets).

Infrared radiationradiationinfrared radiation (or heat in the form of photons) emitted by Earth’s surface is resonant with various vibrational modes of GHGGreenhouse gas molecules, inducing these photons to be absorbed and re-emitted in all directions. Some of this absorbed and re-emitted radiation is sent back to the surface. As such, GHGs in Earth’s atmosphere act as a blanket, trapping heat that would otherwise escape to space. Water vapor, the most important GHGGreenhouse gas, is responsible for the majority of radiation sent back to the surface. The abundance of H2Owater in our atmosphere is controlled by thermodynamics: i.e., the evaporation of H2Owater from the oceans, condensation of H2Owater in the atmosphere to form cloudsclouds, and deposition of H2Owater back to the surface in the form of precipitation. Atmospheric H2Owater varied prior to the onset of human influence; the effect of thermodynamics on various isotopes of H2Owater preserved in ice coresice cores is an important tool for quantitative reconstruction of past climate (Jouzel et al. 1987).

The radiative forcingradiative forcing (RF) of climate refers to the increase in the amount of heat directed to Earth’s lower atmosphere as the abundance of GHGs rise. Here and throughout this book, we follow the convention established in the 2001 Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCCIntergovernmental Panel on Climate Change) Physical Science Basic Report (IPCC 2001) that RF ofradiative forcing climate is defined as the change in the net flow of energy (sunlight plus infrared heat) at the tropopausetropopause (boundary between the lower atmosphere, or tropospheretroposphere, and the upper atmosphere, or stratospherestratosphere) relative to a particular start date, after allowing for stratospheric temperatures to adjust to radiative equilibrium. This concept is explained well in Sect. 2.2 of IPCC (2007).

Figure 1.3a shows several time series of the RF ofradiative forcing climate over the AnthropoceneAnthropocene. The curves are set to zero in year 1765 and represent changes relative to this start time, hence they are denoted ΔRFradiative forcing.2 Red is used to represent warming (positive ΔRFradiative forcing); blue is used to show cooling (negative ΔRFradiative forcing). These ΔRFradiative forcing curves are based on the GHGGreenhouse gas and aerosol precursor abundances used to drive climate model simulations of IPCCIntergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (2013). The RF ofradiative forcing climate due to human release of CO2carbon dioxide, CH4methane, and N2Onitrous oxide is the primary focus of this book. The historic ΔRFradiative forcing due to all anthropogenic GHGs (dashed red) exceeds that of the CO2carbon dioxide/CH4methane/N2Onitrous oxide triplet (dotted red) by a small amount, with most of the difference due to a class of compounds called Ozone Depleting Substances (ODSOzone Depleting Substances). Even though ODSOzone Depleting Substances exhibit a greenhouse effectgreenhouse effect, they are generally not labeled as GHGs because their most important detrimental effect is depletion of Earth’s ozone layer. Also, industrial production of ODSOzone Depleting Substances has been successfully curtailed by the Montreal ProtocolMontreal Protocol and the effect of these compounds on climate will diminish in the future (WMO 2014).Fig. 1.3
Radiative forcing of climate and temperature, AnthropoceneAnthropocene. (a) change in the radiative forcingradiative forcing of climate (ΔRFradiative forcing) relative to year 1765, from various factors (as indicated) for the RCPRepresentative Concentration Pathway 4.5 scenario (Meinshausen et al. 2011); (b) total anthropogenic ΔRFradiative forcing (red) and the global mean surface temperatureglobal mean surface temperature anomaly (ΔTGMST anomaly) relative to pre-industrial baseline (1850–1900 mean) from the modern instrument record (HadCRUT4) (Jones et al. 2012) and from various proxies (Jones and Mann 2004). See Methods for further information

The human release of pollutants that increase the burden of small particles in the tropospheretroposphere, known as aerosolsaerosols, leads to a reduction in the RF ofradiative forcing climate (blue line, Fig. 1.3a). This occurs because many aerosols reflect sunlight. An estimate of ΔRFradiative forcing due to aerosols provided by Meinshausen et al. (2011) is shown in Fig. 1.3a.3 As detailed below, there is considerable uncertainty in this term.

The total ΔRFradiative forcing due to human activity is shown by the solid red curve in Fig. 1.3a, b. All told, human activities have increased the RF ofradiative forcing climate by about 2.3 W m−2 between 1750 and present. Figure 1.3b shows that the time variation of total ΔRFradiative forcing due to humans (red line) closely resembles the observed rise in global mean surface temperatureglobal mean surface temperature anomaly (black and grey lines). Below we conduct quantitative analysis of these two quantities, both within this chapter as well as throughout Chap. 2.

Figure 1.4 details the change in RF ofradiative forcing climate, between 1750 and 2011, due to various factors.4 Numerical values are from Chap. 8 of IPCC (2013). Error bars denote the 5 and 95 % confidence intervals for each quantity. Processes that effect RF ofradiative forcing climate but are not regulated under GHGGreenhouse gas legislation, such as Stratospheric and Tropospheric Ozone and Land Use Changeland use change, as well as minor terms such as Contrails and Solar Irradiance, are also shown. The solid red lines of Fig. 1.3 consider all of the terms shown in Fig. 1.4.Fig. 1.4
Radiative forcing of climate, various factors, AnthropoceneAnthropocene. Change in radiative forcingradiative forcing of climate (ΔRFradiative forcing) over the course of the Anthropocene (in this case, 1750–2011) due to human factors (GHGs and aerosolsaerosols) and natural processes (solar irradiance). Error bars represent the 5–95 % confidence interval. The ODSOzone Depleting Substances entry represents ΔRFradiative forcing due to ozone depleting substances such as CFC-11, CFC-12minor GHGschlorofluorocarbons, etc. The Other F-gases entry represents ΔRFradiative forcing due to HFCsminor GHGshydrofluorocarbons, PFCsminor GHGsperfluorocarbons, SF6minor GHGssulfur hexafluoride, and NF3. Numerical estimates for ΔRFradiative forcing are shown when available; otherwise, numerical estimates for the change in Effective Radiative Forcingradiative forcing (ΔERF) are used. After Fig. 8.15 of IPCC (2013). See Methods for further information

There are several aspects of Fig. 1.4 worth emphasizing. Human release of GHGs has warmed climate, with CO2carbon dioxide being the most important contributor. The combined effect of the two other most important long-lived anthropogenic GHGs (CH4methane, N2Onitrous oxide) plus all of the ODSOzone Depleting Substances compounds has enhanced this CO2carbon dioxide-based warming by about 60 %. Tropospheric ozoneozonetropospheric (O3), a pollutant harmful to human health and agricultureagriculture, has warmed climate over the course of the AnthropoceneAnthropocene by nearly as much as CH4methane. Tropospheric O3ozonetropospheric is regulated by air quality regulations that vary by country and focus on surface conditions (i.e., the air we breathe). There is no coordinated international effort to limit future growth of tropospheric O3ozonetropospheric. Human release of pollutants that lead to formation of tropospheric aerosolsaerosols causes climate to cool due to two processes nearly equal in magnitude but having large uncertainty: the reflection of sunlight by aerosols (Aerosol Direct Effect) and the effect of aerosols on cloud formation (Aerosol-Cloud Interaction).5 The net effect of all human activity on ΔRFradiative forcing (bar labeled Total Anthropogenic) is about 25 % larger than ΔRFradiative forcing due to CO2carbon dioxide and has a considerably larger uncertainty (size of respective error bars) (Chap. 8, IPCC (2013)).

Other aspects of global warmingglobal warming are represented in Fig. 1.4. The reflectivity of Earth’s surface has changed primarily due to deforestation that makes the surface brighter (leading to cooling) and the deposition of dark, carbonaceous material on snow that darkens the surface (leading to warming). Contrails from aircraft have led to a slight warming, mainly because of induced cloudsclouds. A slight warming term is also attributed to an increase in stratospheric humidity driven by rising tropospheric CH4methane, which is converted to H2Owater when lost in the stratospherestratosphere. The depletion of stratospheric O3ozonestratospheric has resulted in slight cooling. Finally and most importantly, scientists have been able to estimate the time variation of total solar irradiance over the course of the AnthropoceneAnthropocene. The trend in solar irradiance over this two and a half century time period is small. Even if the MWPMedieval Warm Period discussed above turns out to be as warm as the present decades, presumably due to an increase in solar irradiance during the middle of the Common Era (Bard et al. 2000), scientists are nonetheless confident the rise in temperature over the Anthropocene was driven by rising GHGs and not a change in the luminosity of our Sun (Chap. 8, IPCC (2013)).

sec.title: Global Warming Potential
sec.p: The global warming potential (GWPglobal warming potential) metric was developed to guide public policy decisions regarding trade-offs of release of various GHGs. The GWPglobal warming potential of a particular compound represents the ratio of the rise in global mean surface temperatureglobal mean surface temperature (GMSTglobal mean surface temperature) due to the release of a particular amount (mass) of this compound, relative to the rise in GMSTglobal mean surface temperature resulting from the release of the same amount (mass) of CO2carbon dioxide. Inherent in the computation of GWPglobal warming potential is that the increase in GMSTglobal mean surface temperature is found over a particular time horizon.

As shown in Chap. 3, the GWPglobal warming potential of various GHGs is vitally important for assessing the efficacy of the Paris Climate Agreement7Paris Climate Agreement. Table 1.1 provides the GWPglobal warming potential of CH4methane and N2Onitrous oxide from the past 4 IPCCIntergovernmental Panel on Climate Change reports. The GWPglobal warming potential of GHGs has been updated over time due to evolving knowledge of the radiative efficiencies and lifetimes of atmospheric compounds. The most commonly used GWPsglobal warming potential for public policy are those found for a 100-year time horizon. This preference is traceable to the 1997 KyotoKyoto Protocol Protocol of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCCUnited Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change), which was based on 100-year GWPsglobal warming potential. Furthermore, since the values of GWPglobal warming potential given in IPCC (2013) that do not allow for carbon cycle feedbackcarbon cyclefeedback are most analogous to values of GWPsglobal warming potential given in prior IPCCIntergovernmental Panel on Climate Change reports, we will use GWPsglobal warming potential for CH4methane and N2Onitrous oxide of 28 and 265, respectively, in our analysis of the Paris Climate Agreement. The GWPsglobal warming potential of other GHGsminor GHGs used in our analysis are based on Chap. 8 of IPCC (2013).

The fact that the GWPsglobal warming potential of CH4methane and N2Onitrous oxide are much larger than 1 means that, on a per mass basis, these GHGs are considerably more potent than CO2carbon dioxide.8 Furthermore, the GWPglobal warming potential of CH4methane is much larger over a 20-year horizon than a 100-year time horizon, due to the 12.4 year lifetime for CH4methane used in the calculation of GWPglobal warming potential. Integrated over 20 years, a significant fraction of the initial, pulsed release of CH4methane is present in the modeled atmosphere. However, integrated over 100 years, a much smaller fraction is present. As discussed in Chap. 4, controlling inadvertent release of CH4methane to the atmosphere will likely be vitally important for reaching the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement, keeping warming well below 2.0 °C and aiming to limit warming to 1.5 °CParis Climate Agreement. The importance of CH4methane would be amplified by a factor of 3 (ratio of 84/28 from Table 1.1) if climate change over a 20-year time horizon were used to guide public policy, placing even more stringent controls on the atmospheric release of this GHGGreenhouse gas.

Carbon dioxide is the most important anthropogenic GHGGreenhouse gas for RF ofradiative forcing climate (Figs. 1.3a and 1.4), despite the more potent nature of CH4methane and N2Onitrous oxide, because human society has released to the atmosphere a much greater mass of CO2carbon dioxide than other GHGsminor GHGs. Simply put, CO2carbon dioxide is the greatest waste-product of modern society. We now turn our attention towards the human fingerprints on global warmingglobal warming as well as on the atmospheric build-up of CO2carbon dioxide and other GHGsminor GHGs.

sec.title: Human Fingerprints
sec.p: As described in Sect. 1.1, Earth’s climate has undergone vast variations on geologic time scales. Many of these climate shifts are directly tied to changes in atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide. Studies of paleoclimate must also consider effects on global mean surface temperatureglobal mean surface temperature (GMSTglobal mean surface temperature) of continental plate alignment (Hay et al. 1990), the seasonal distribution of sunlight related to variations of Earth’s orbitMilankovitch cycles (Erb et al. 2013), as well as the radiative forcingradiative forcing of climate due to aerosolsaerosols (Chylek and Lohmann 2008) and GHGs other than CO2carbon dioxide (Sagan and Mullen 1972).

Even though Earth’s climate and the abundance of GHGs co-vary on geologic time scales due to natural processes, a scientific consensus has nonetheless emerged that the recent rise in GMSTglobal mean surface temperature as well as atmospheric burdens of CO2carbon dioxide, CH4methane, and N2Onitrous oxide are all driven by human activities (IPCC 2013). Here we briefly review some of the most important human fingerprints on temperature and GHGs. To place the material that follows in the proper perspective, it is important to understand that the time scales involved with geologic change and human history are enormously different. For instance, the ratio of the time since the rise of forests (400 Mypb) to the time since the advent of agricultureagriculture (~12,000 ybp) is enormous. If time on Earth since the rise of forests were compressed into a 24 h day, the time since the advent of agriculture would take 2.6 s, which is less than the time it takes to read this sentence!

sec.title: Rising Temperature
sec.p: As noted above, correlation does not demonstrate causation. We shall first examine the quantitative relation between the rise in the GMSTglobal mean surface temperature anomaly (ΔTGMST anomaly) shown in Fig. 1.3 and the change in radiative forcingradiative forcing of climate (ΔRFradiative forcing) attributed to humans over the AnthropoceneAnthropocene.

Several other aspects of global warmingglobal warming bear the human fingerprint. Climate models predict that as GHGs rise, the lowest layer of the atmosphere (the tropospheretroposphere) will warm while the second layer of the atmosphere (the stratospherestratosphere) should cool. Stratospheric coolingstratospherecooling is a consequence of the blanketing effect of GHGs: as atmospheric levels of GHGs rise, a larger fraction of the thermal energy emitted by the surface is absorbed, re-emitted, and therefore blocked from reaching the stratosphere. As shown in Fig. 1.5, tropospheric warmingglobal warming coupled with stratospheric cooling is seen in the climate record, at least over the part of the AnthropoceneAnthropocene for which modern measurements of atmospheric temperature profiles exist (Sherwood and Nishant 2015). About two-thirds of the cooling of the upper stratosphere for the time period 1979–2005 has been attributed to rising GHGs, with the remainder attributed to human-induced depletion of stratospheric O3Ozone Depleting Substancesozonestratospheric (Mitchell 2016). The pattern of temperature changes with respect to altitude and latitude throughout the troposphere and stratosphere agrees with the pattern predicted by climate models to a high degree of statistical significance (Santer et al. 2013a), although these models do tend to overestimate the amount of warming observed in the lower atmosphere (Santer et al. 2013b).10Fig. 1.5
Temperature change profile, 1959–2012. Temperature difference, 1959–2012, based on analysis of radiosonde observations acquired between latitudes of 30°S and 30°N (positive values indicate warming). After Sherwood and Nishant (2015) except we use altitude, rather than pressure, for the vertical coordinate. See Methods for further information

Another important human fingerprint of global warmingglobal warming is the observation that the altitude of the tropopausetropopause, the boundary between the tropospheretroposphere and the stratospherestratosphere, has been rising as predicted by climate models (Santer et al. 2013a). Had modern global warming been due to an increase in the luminosity of the Sun or a release of energy from the world’s oceans, scientists would have expected to observe warming in the stratosphere and troposphere as well as little to no change in the height of the tropopause.

sec.title: Carbon Dioxide
sec.p: Carbon dioxide (CO2carbon dioxide) is the single greatest waste product of modern society. There is compelling scientific evidence that the rise in atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide during the AnthropoceneAnthropocene is due, nearly entirely, to human activity. The rise in CO2carbon dioxide from 1765 to the early 1900s was predominately driven by the clearing of forests for agricultureagriculture (also known as land use changeland use change, or LUCland use change) (Siegenthaler and Oeschger 1987). For a few decades subsequent to 1900, LUCland use change and the combustion of fossil fuelsfossil fuels made nearly equal contributions to the rise in atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide. Since the early 1950s, the growth of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide has been driven primarily by the combustion of fossil fuels11 (Le Quéré et al. 2015).

Precise quantification of the contemporary abundance of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide was initiated by Charles David Keeling at the Mauna Loa Observatory (MLOMauna Loa Observatory) in Hawaii during March 1958, as part of the International Geophysical Year (IGY) program (Keeling et al. 1976). On the first day of measurement, an atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide abundance of 313 parts per million (ppm) was recorded.12 The MLOMauna Loa ObservatoryCO2carbon dioxide record is a signature accomplishment of the IGY, carried out from July 1957 to December 1958 and characterized by international cooperation on many scientific fronts. The ability of nations such as the United States and the Soviet Union to collaborate on IGY, despite the Cold War, serves as an inspiration for the level of international cooperation that will be needed to address the consequences of rising GHGs recorded at the Mauna Loa observatory.

On the day this sentence was written, atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide at MLOMauna Loa Observatory was 407.66 ppm. This CO2carbon dioxide reading amounts to a thirty percent increase relative to Keeling’s first observation and a forty-five percent increase relative to 280 ppm, the atmospheric mixing ratio of CO2carbon dioxide commonly assumed to have been present at the start of the AnthropoceneAnthropocene. Daily measurements of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide are provided at various websites, including https://www.co2.earth/daily-co2.

We now describe the scientific evidence that humans are responsible for the rise of CO2carbon dioxide. Our focus is on 1959 to present, the modern instrument era. Readers interested in learning about the human impact on CO2carbon dioxide over the earlier part of the AnthropoceneAnthropocene (i.e., prior to 1959) are encouraged to examine studies such as Siegenthaler and Oeschger (1987), Ruddiman (2003), Le Quéré et al. (2015), and Steffen et al. (2015).

Figure 1.6 shows time series of the atmospheric build-up of CO2carbon dioxide and fossil fuelfossil fuels emissions of CO2carbon dioxide, from 1959 to present. Measurement of CO2carbon dioxide at MLOMauna Loa Observatory (Keeling et al. 1976) and an estimate of global mean CO2carbon dioxide provided by the US National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAANational Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration) Earth System Research Laboratory (ESRLEarth System Research Laboratory) (Ballantyne et al. 2012) are shown in Fig. 1.6a. The saw-tooth pattern of the MLOMauna Loa ObservatoryCO2carbon dioxide reveals the breathing of the biosphere: seasonal minimum occurs in late boreal summer just before deciduous treesplantstrees, which predominantly exist in the NH, begin to drop their leaves. Seasonal maximum occurs in mid-spring of the NH, just before treesplantstrees and plantsplants bloom. The global, annual record of CO2carbon dioxide exhibits a steady upward march over the past six decades.Fig. 1.6

See Methods for further information

Figure 1.6b provides our first evidence that humans are responsible for the rise of CO2carbon dioxide over the past six decades. This panel compares the annual, global release of CO2carbon dioxide to the atmosphere due to the combustion of fossil fuelsfossil fuels (Boden et al. 2013) and land use changeland use change (Houghton et al. 2012) (green bars) to the annual rise in global atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide (blue bars); both quantities are expressed in units of 109 metric tons of CO2carbon dioxide (Gt CO2carbon dioxide) emitted per year.13 In some years, such as 1977, 1979, 1987, 1988, and 1998, the rise in atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide is more than half of the CO2carbon dioxide input to the atmosphere by humans (i.e., the height of the blue bar is more than half the height of the green bar). Typically, the annual rise in the mass of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide (blue bars) equals between 40 and 50 % of the mass of CO2carbon dioxide released to the atmosphere by humans (green bars). This comparison demonstrates quantitative plausibility that the observed rise in atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide during the modern instrument era was indeed due to human activity.

Figure 1.7 illustrates the three most important pieces of observational evidence that scientists use to reveal the human fingerprint on rising CO2carbon dioxide. Time series of the mixing ratio of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide measured at MLOMauna Loa Observatory in Hawaii (19.82°N latitude) are compared to CO2carbon dioxide measured at the South Pole Observatory (SPOSouth Pole Observatory) in Fig. 1.7a. Figure 1.8 compares the difference between annual averages of CO2carbon dioxide at MLOMauna Loa Observatory and SPOSouth Pole Observatory (ΔCO2MLO−SPOSouth Pole Observatory) for specific years plotted against the total human release of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide for each particular year. Figures 1.7a and 1.8 show that CO2carbon dioxide is higher in the NH than the Southern Hemisphere (SH). This hemispheric gradient has long been used as evidence for the human influence on atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide, since anthropogenic emissions occur predominantly in the NH (Tans et al. 1990). The strong correlation of ΔCO2MLO−SPOSouth Pole Observatory versus total human release of CO2carbon dioxide shown in Fig. 1.8 further demonstrates that the anthropogenic activity exerts primary control on the hemispheric gradient in atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide (Fan et al. 1999).Fig. 1.7

Figure 1.7b illustrates the small decline of atmospheric O2, which is another fingerprint of the human influence on rising CO2carbon dioxide (see Methods for an explanation of the units and numbers). As CO2carbon dioxide is released to the atmosphere by the combustion of fossil fuelfossil fuels, the oxygen (O) content of the newly emitted CO2carbon dioxide comes from atmospheric molecular oxygen (O2).14 If rising atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide were due to volcanicvolcanic activity activity or deep sea ventsdeep sea vents, atmospheric O2 would be unaffected because the dominant form of outgassed carbon is CO2carbon dioxide, with the O drawn from abundant oxygen in Earth’s crust. Measurement of atmospheric O2 with sufficient precision to quantify the minute, putative decline was an instrumental challenge first overcome by Ralph Keeling (Keeling et al. 1996), the son of Charles David Keeling. The slight decline in atmospheric O2 recorded in Fig. 1.7b provides strong quantitative evidence that combustion of fossil fuelfossil fuels is the driving factor behind rising CO2carbon dioxide.

The final human fingerprint involves the isotopic composition of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide. The most common form of carbon has an atomic mass of 12 (12C), due to the presence of six protons and six neutrons in the nucleus.15 Carbon can exist in two other forms: carbon 13 (13C) and carbon 14 (14C), due to the presence of either 7 (13C) or 8 (14C) neutrons in the nucleus. The chemical properties of a compound are determined by the number of electrons, which equals the number of protons if a compound is neutral (i.e., uncharged). Hence 12C, 13C, and 14C are all considered to be different forms of carbon because they all contain six electrons. Most importantly, biological properties of a compound are mass dependent: our bodies prefer 12C over the other two heavier forms of carbon that are digested, because lighter molecules diffuse more readily through our capillaries. The term isotopic composition, as used here, refers to the relative abundance of 13C in a sample of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide compared to the sum of 12C, 13C, and 14C in the same sample, and is expressed using the notation δ13C.

Figure 1.7c shows a time series of δ13C recorded at MLOMauna Loa Observatory (Keeling et al. 2005). The downward decline of δ13C means atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide is getting isotopically lighter over time. In other words, at the start of the time series in 1980, the relative proportion of 13C to 12C in atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide at Hawaii was larger than today. This serves as our final fingerprint because the carbon content of fossil fuelsfossil fuels, which formed from the decomposition of plantsplants on geologic time-scales, are isotopically light relative to contemporary atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide (Whiticar 1996). If rising levels of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide during the time period shown in Fig. 1.7c had been due primarily to volcanoes, atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide would have been expected to have gotten isotopically heavier (Rizzo et al. 2014), which is the opposite of what has been observed.

It is stated in Sect. 1.1 that over geologic time scales, atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide is controlled by volcanicvolcanic activity activity and deep sea ventsdeep sea vents. Yet CO2carbon dioxide shows no volcanicvolcanic activity influence over the time of the modern instrument record. To further illustrate the lack of recent volcanicvolcanic activity influence, the orange triangles in Fig. 1.6b have been placed at the time of eruption of Mount Agung, El Chichón, and Mount Pinatubo, the three largest eruptions over the past six decades. The growth of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide during the years of these eruptions (1963, 1982, and 1991) is unremarkable compared to other years: in fact, the growth of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide (blue bars) after the eruption of Mt. Agung (1963) and Mt. Pinatubo (1991) is suppressed relative to prior years. The best estimate of contemporary release of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide by volcanoes and deep sea vents reveals release of about 0.26 Gt of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide per year (Marty and Tolstikhin 1998), less than 1 % of the human burden. Interestingly and with touching irony for those who refuse to accept the human influence on global warmingglobal warming, the volcanicvolcanic activity release of CO2carbon dioxide during the 9 h explosive phase of Mt. Pinatubo on 15 June 1991 likely matched the total, global release of CO2carbon dioxide by humans on that day (Gerlach 2011). More than 20,000 days have passed since the start of modern measurements of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide. On one day and one day only, global human release of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide was likely matched by a volcano. Human release of CO2carbon dioxide has dwarfed volcanicvolcanic activity release on the other 19,999 days.

Why have volcanoes been so dominant in the past, yet so unimportant in the present? One factor is that modern human civilization has not yet experienced a volcanicvolcanic activity eruption of the magnitude known to have occurred in the past. The Volcanic Explosivity Index (VEIVolcanic Explosivity Index) denotes the size of volcanicvolcanic activity eruptions (Newhall and Self 1982), much like the Richter Scale for earthquakes. Mt. Agung, El Chichón, and Mt. Pinatubo had VEIs of 5, 5, and 6, respectively. The most violent eruption Earth has experienced over the past 36 million years was the VEIVolcanic Explosivity Index of 9.1–9.2 eruption of La Garita16 about 27.8 Mypb (Mason et al. 2004). Since the VEIVolcanic Explosivity Index scale is logarithmic with respect to volume of ejecta, a VEIVolcanic Explosivity Index 9 eruption would eject about 1000 times more mass than Mt. Pinatubo.17 Had Mt. Pinatubo been VEIVolcanic Explosivity Index 9, it may have matched human emission of CO2carbon dioxide over the prior 1000 days. In this case, of course, the ejection of CO2carbon dioxide by such a monstrous event would have been the least of our concerns.

The other factor responsible for the minor role of volcanoes with respect to contemporary atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide is that Earth is presently in a geologically dormant period. The Deccan Traps of India is one of the largest, most well-studied ancient volcanicvolcanic activity features on Earth. Eruptions of this massive province, approximately 65 Mybp, may have been characterized by a decades-long explosive events (Self et al. 2006). The perturbation to atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide by the Deccan Traps is the subject of active research, with some studies (Dessert et al. 2001) suggesting a considerably larger influence than others (Self et al. 2006).

We conclude by providing a brief overview of the latest understanding of the factors that control atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide. More detailed information, updated annually, is maintained at http://www.globalcarbonproject.org/carbonbudget.

It is well established that a substantial portion of the CO2carbon dioxide released to the atmosphere by human activity is absorbed by treesplantstrees and plantsplants (i.e., the terrestrial biosphere) as well as the world’s oceans (Le Quéré et al. 2015). Uptake of anthropogenic CO2carbon dioxide by plants is facilitated by three factors: higher levels of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide promote faster growth of plants (Zhu et al. 2016), global warmingglobal warming has increased the length of the growing season (Le Quéré et al. 2015), and human supply of fixed nitrogen to the biosphere promotes a more fertile environment for plant growth (Galloway et al. 2014). The world’s oceans contain a mass of carbon about 50 times greater than that in the atmosphere and it has long been known that the world’s oceans would uptake a portion of the CO2carbon dioxide placed into the atmosphere by human activities (Revelle and Suess 1957).

An atmospheric and oceanic phenomena known as El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSOEl Niño Southern Oscillation) has been extensively studied as a driving factor for the variation of the height of the blue bars (atmospheric growth of CO2carbon dioxide) relative to the green bars (human release of CO2carbon dioxide) shown in Fig. 1.6b (Keeling et al. 2005; Randerson et al. 2005; Zeng et al. 2005). When the index shown in Fig. 1.6c is shaded dark red for a period of ~5 months or longer, the tropical ocean/atmosphere system is in the midst of an ENSOEl Niño Southern Oscillation event.18 The growth of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide tends to be larger than normal for about a year after the peak of an ENSOEl Niño Southern Oscillation event, with the effect maximizing about 6 months after the peak (Zeng et al. 2005). An ENSOEl Niño Southern Oscillation event affects atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide due to suppression of oceanic uptake as well as the tendency for human-set fires to occur in drought stricken regions during certain ENSOEl Niño Southern Oscillation years (Randerson et al. 2005). During late 2015, Earth experienced another major ENSOEl Niño Southern Oscillation event, which likely was responsible for the more rapid rise of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide in 2015 compared to prior years. Indeed, the preliminary estimate of total human release of CO2carbon dioxide in year 2015 given by Le Quéré et al. (2015), which is the origin of the last green bar in Fig. 1.6b, shows a slight decline relative to 2014. Should this decline in human release of CO2carbon dioxide continue in future years, the height of the blue bars in future updates to Fig. 1.6b will fall relative to the value for 2015, except for years marked by either large ENSOEl Niño Southern Oscillation events and/or extensive biomass burningaerosolsbiomass burning.

The fraction of anthropogenic CO2carbon dioxide removed each year via the world’s terrestrial biosphere and oceans is depicted by the grey bars in Fig. 1.6d. There is considerable year-to-year variability, which has been widely studied and is attributed mainly to terrestrial biosphere (Bousquet et al. 2000; Le Quéré et al. 2003). Averaged over the entire data record, 56 % of the CO2carbon dioxide released to the atmosphere by humans by the combustion of fossil fuels and land use change has been absorbed by land and ocean sinks. In other words, the actual rise in atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide equals about 44 % of that known to have been emitted by humans.

The efficiency of the combined land and ocean sinkcarbon dioxidesinks for atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide appears to be weakening over time. Figure 1.6d contains two lines. One shows a 3 year running mean (black) of the numerical values of each grey bar, for data starting in 1959 and ending in 2014. Values for 2015 are excluded from the 3 year running mean, because data for this year are considered preliminary at the time of writing. An entity such as a 3 year running mean is a common statistical method used to analyze data that exhibit a large amount of year-to-year variability, such as the grey bars in Fig. 1.6d. The trend-line (blue) shows a linear least squares fit to the 3 year running mean, another common technique used to examine geophysical data. The trend-line has a slope of −0.0013 per year, which means the fraction of anthropogenic CO2carbon dioxide removed by the combined land and ocean sinkcarbon dioxidesinks may have declined from about 0.6 in 1959 to about 0.53 in 2014. However, there is considerable uncertainty (in this case, ±0.0014 per year) in the slope of the trend fit line. This uncertainty encompasses (albeit, just barely) the possibility that the combined land and ocean sinkcarbon dioxidesinks may not have actually changed and also, at the same time, another possibility that this uptake could have changed from 0.6 in 1959 to 0.45 in 2014. This analysis builds upon the work and supports the conclusions of Le Quéré (2010), who also emphasize the urgent need to reduce the uncertainty in the time rate of change of the combined land and ocean sinkcarbon dioxidesinks for human release of atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide. If the efficiency of the combined land and ocean sinkcarbon dioxidesinks for CO2carbon dioxide is truly declining over time, then this is enormously important for the response of society to anthropogenic release of GHGs.

sec.title: Methane
sec.p: Methane (CH4methane) is a vitally important anthropogenic GHGGreenhouse gas. The atmospheric abundance of CH4methane has risen from a pre-AnthropoceneAnthropocene value of 0.7 ppm to a contemporary abundance of 1.84 ppm (Fig. 1.2). The rise in CH4methane between 1750 and 2011 has induced a RF ofradiative forcing climate of 0.48 W m−2 (Fig. 1.4), second only to the RF ofradiative forcingCO2carbon dioxide among anthropogenic GHGs.19 Methane is therefore commonly referred to as the second most important anthropogenic GHGGreenhouse gas.

Studies of atmospheric CH4methane are numerous, complex, and quite varied, owing to a variety of natural and human sourcesmethanesources (see Kirschke et al. (2013) and references therein). Figure 1.9 shows an estimate of the sources (i.e., flux into the atmosphere) of CH4methane, in units of 1012 g of CH4methane (Tg CH4methane) emitted per year,20 averaged over the decade 2000–2009 from Conrad (2009) and Kirschke et al. (2013). The figure also contains an estimate of the sinksmethanesinks (i.e., atmospheric loss) of CH4methane over the same period of time.Fig. 1.9
Global methane budget. Source and sinks of atmospheric methane, over the decade 2000–2009, expressed as flux either into or out of the atmosphere. After Conrad (2009) and Kirschke et al. (2013). Human and natural sources, as well as components of all terms, are indicated. See Methods for further information

A number of scientifically important details regarding atmospheric CH4methane are contained in Fig. 1.9. First, the magnitude of the source is slightly larger than the sinkmethanesinks, consistent with the fact that atmospheric CH4methane is rising. Also, there are various human and natural sourcesmethanesources of considerable magnitude. As noted above, wetlands are the largest natural source of CH4methane. Other natural sources include termites and the release of CH4methane from gas hydrates.21 Finally, anthropogenic production of CH4methane occurs due to many aspects of our industrialized world, including the fossil fuelfossil fuels industry, human set fires (biomass burningaerosolsbiomass burning), microbial processes in the stomachs of ruminants,22 as well as anaerobic conditions common in rice paddies and landfills. As detailed in Chap. 4, if human release of methane is to be curtailed, many aspects of modern society will need to be addressed, including how we heat our homes, generate our electricity, and produce our food.

Two considerable complications for the proper accounting of the human releasemethanesources of CH4methane are posed by possible alteration of the wetland source due to climate-change induced changes of the hydrologic cycle (i.e., floods and drought) as well as the possible release of prodigious amounts of CH4methane from the Arctic as permafrost thaws, due to global warmingglobal warming (Koven et al. 2011). For now, at least, the source of CH4methane due to Arctic permafrost is small on a global scale (Kirschke et al. 2013).

The ~10 year atmospheric lifetimemethanesinks for CH4methane has important policy implications. This is best illustrated by comparing the human release of CH4methane to that of CO2carbon dioxide. Throughout the world, humans presently release about 335 Tg of CH4methane and 39 Gt of CO2carbon dioxide per year. Since 1000 Tg = 1 Gt, these sourcesmethanesources are 0.335 Gt of CH4methane and 39 Gt of CO2carbon dioxide per year: i.e., the mass of CO2carbon dioxide released to the atmosphere each year by human society is about 116 times more than the mass of CH4methane. The impact on climate is entirely dependent on the time scale of interest. Nearly all of the CH4methane released to the atmosphere in year 2015 will be gone by the end of this century. The CO2carbon dioxide-equivalent emission of CH4methane, found by multiplying the current release by the GWPglobal warming potential for CH4methane for a 100-year time horizon, is 28 × 0.335 Gt of CH4methane or 9.4 Gt per year. If our concern is global warmingglobal warming over the next century, then we would conclude the human release of CO2carbon dioxide in year 2015 was about four times more harmful for climate (39 ÷ 9.4 = 4.1) than the release of CH4methane. However, if our concern is the next two decades, we must consider the GWPglobal warming potential of CH4methane over a 20-year time horizon. In this case, the CO2carbon dioxide-equivalent emission of CH4methane is 84 × 0.335 Gt or 28.1 Gt per year, and we would conclude the present human release of CH4methane is nearly as harmful for climate (28.1 versus 39) as the release of CO2carbon dioxide.

As noted above, international policy for the regulation of GHGs generally utilizes GWPsglobal warming potential found over a 100-year time horizon. Perhaps this is appropriate, given CO2carbon dioxide is such a long-lived GHGGreenhouse gas (i.e., a CO2carbon dioxide molecule released today by humans will likely persist in the atmosphere longer than a molecule CH4methane). However, should the world ever face an impending climate catastrophe in the midst of rapidly rising abundances of both atmospheric CO2carbon dioxide and CH4methane, the greatest leverage for near-immediate relief will be to reduce anthropogenic emissions of CH4methane (Shindell et al. 2009) or other short-lived pollutants (Pierrehumbert 2014). Of course this is much easier stated than accomplished given the wide variety of human activitiesmethanesources that release CH4methane, as well as the tendency for energy production in the United States to become increasingly more CH4methane-based, given the abundant source of natural gasnatural gas now being extracted by frackingnatural gasfracking.24

sec.title: Nitrous Oxide, Ozone, and Ozone Depleting Substances
sec.p: Nitrous oxide (N2Onitrous oxide) is commonly considered to be the third most important anthropogenic GHGGreenhouse gas. The atmospheric abundance of N2Onitrous oxide has risen from a pre-AnthropoceneAnthropocene value of 0.273 ppm to a contemporary abundance of 0.329 ppm (Fig. 1.2). The rise in N2Onitrous oxide between 1750 and 2011 has induced a RF ofradiative forcing climate of 0.17 W m−2 (Fig. 1.4).

Nitrous oxide is long-lived, with a lifetime of about 120 years. The vast majority of the atmospheric lossnitrous oxidesinks of N2Onitrous oxide occurs in the stratospherestratosphere (Minschwaner et al. 1993). Nitrous oxide has a GWPglobal warming potential of 264 (20-year time horizon) or 265 (100-year time horizon) (Table 1.1) according to IPCC (2013). The GWPglobal warming potential of N2Onitrous oxide is nearly the same for both time horizons because a pulse of N2Onitrous oxide released to the atmosphere decays, within models used to calculate GWPsglobal warming potential, in a manner quite similar to the decay of a pulse of CO2carbon dioxide.

Current best understanding of the human sourcesnitrous oxidesources of N2Onitrous oxide is described in Chap. 6 of IPCC (2013). The total anthropogenic source is estimated to be 21.7 Tg of N2Onitrous oxide per year,27 albeit with considerable uncertainty. The human source could be as low as 8.5 or as high as 34.9 Tg N2Onitrous oxide per year according to Table 6.9 of IPCC (2013). Prather et al. (2012) report a smaller best estimate for the human source of 20.4 Tg N2Onitrous oxide per year, with a reduced uncertainty of ±4 Tg N2Onitrous oxide per year. Agricultureagriculture is the dominant activity responsible for human release of N2Onitrous oxide: use of nitrogen fertilizers results in release of N2Onitrous oxide to the atmosphere due to microbial processes in soils (Smith et al. 1997). Contemporary human emissions of N2Onitrous oxide presently make a contribution to global warmingglobal warming28 that is ~15 % that of emissions of CO2carbon dioxide.

The largest natural sourcesnitrous oxidesources of N2Onitrous oxide are production from soils that lie beneath vegetation unperturbed by humans and release from the world’s oceans. The natural source is estimated to be 34.6 Tg of N2Onitrous oxide per year, again with considerable uncertainty (range from 17.0 to 61.6 Tg of N2Onitrous oxide per year) (IPCC 2013). Large uncertainties for both the human and natural sources of N2Onitrous oxide, as well as the long atmospheric lifetime for N2Onitrous oxide, preclude meaningful use of Eq. 1.8 to examine the consistency between the rise in N2Onitrous oxide and our understanding of the natural and anthropogenic source strengths. Nonetheless, the long-term rise in N2Onitrous oxide since 1977, the observation of larger abundances in the NH than the SH documented on websites such as http://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/hats/combined/N2Onitrous oxide, and field measurements of strong anthropogenic sourcesnitrous oxidesources (Table 6.9 of IPCC (2013)) all provide strong scientific evidence that humans are responsible for the vast majority of the rise in N2Onitrous oxide over the course of the AnthropoceneAnthropocene.

The possible increase in atmospheric N2Onitrous oxide due to expanded use of biofuelsbiofuels will receive considerable attention in the next few decades. There is considerable interest in the development of biofuels as a replacement for fossil fuelsfossil fuels because, in theory, biofuels could be close to carbon neutral. The notion of carbon neutrality is predicated on the fact that the carbon in a hydrocarbon fuel produced by recent photosynthesisphotosynthesis has been drawn out of the atmosphere just prior to combustion: i.e., the carbon is recycled. One of the many concerns regarding the modern biofuel industry is that the associated increase in production of atmospheric N2Onitrous oxide due to the need for additional fertilizer will offset the climate benefit from the supposed carbon neutrality of this new fuel source (Crutzen et al. 2016).

The effect of N2Onitrous oxide on stratospheric O3ozonestratospheric will also likely receive attention by researchers. Loss of N2Onitrous oxide occurs in the stratospherestratosphere and, upon decomposition, N2Onitrous oxide produces compounds that deplete stratospheric ozone (Ravishankara et al. 2009). Most interestingly, the ozone depletion potential29 of N2Onitrous oxide depends on future atmospheric abundances of CO2carbon dioxide and CH4methane (Revell et al. 2015). Not only are CO2carbon dioxide, CH4methane, and N2Onitrous oxide (as well as chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCsminor GHGschlorofluorocarbons) all important for climate, but these compounds are also inextricably linked for the future recovery of Earth’s ozone layer.

While it is certainly true that most scientists consider N2Onitrous oxide to be the third most important anthropogenic GHGGreenhouse gas, it is worth noting that the contribution to the RF ofradiative forcing climate over the course of the AnthropoceneAnthropocene by N2Onitrous oxide is smaller than that of both Ozone Depleting Substances (ODSOzone Depleting Substances) and tropospheric O3ozonetropospheric (Fig. 1.4). Why then is N2Onitrous oxide commonly considered to be the third most important anthropogenic GHGGreenhouse gas? The answer is nuanced but provides insight into the multi-disciplinary nature of modern atmospheric science.

The category labeled ODSOzone Depleting Substances in Fig. 1.4 consists of many gases (see Methods), including numerous CFCsminor GHGschlorofluorocarbons, hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCsminor GHGshydrochlorofluorocarbons), carbon tetrachloride (CCl4), methyl chloroform (CH3CCl3), etc. Industrial production of this class of compounds has been successfully regulated by the Montreal ProtocolMontreal Protocol and subsequent amendments due to the harmful effects of these chemicals on Earth’s protective ozone layer (WMO 2014). It is not commonly appreciated, but the climate protection accomplished by the Montreal Protocol (due to reduction in the atmospheric abundance of ODSOzone Depleting Substances that would have otherwise occurred) far exceeds the climate protection accomplished by the KyotoKyoto Protocol Protocol (Velders et al. 2007). In other words, the positive RF ofradiative forcing climate due to ODSOzone Depleting Substances in Fig. 1.4 would have been much larger had industrial production of these compounds not been halted by the Montreal Protocol. Nonetheless, most scientists do not apply the GHGGreenhouse gas label to the class of chemical compounds that deplete Earth’s ozone layer. Also, none of the ODSOzone Depleting Substances compounds, alone, has a RF ofradiative forcing climate as large as N2Onitrous oxide. So N2Onitrous oxide survives this challenge to its third place status.

The category labeled tropospheric O3ozonetropospheric in Fig. 1.4 also exerts a RF ofradiative forcing climate that exceeds that due to N2Onitrous oxide. Over the course of the AnthropoceneAnthropocene, human release of chemicals such as carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxides produced by biomass burningaerosolsbiomass burning and the combustion of fossil fuelsfossil fuels has led to a build-up of tropospheric ozone, exerting a considerable influence on the RF ofradiative forcing climate (Fig. 1.4). There has also been a slight cooling effect to the decline in stratospheric O3ozonestratospheric over the Anthropocene. Lack of consideration of tropospheric O3ozonetropospheric as the third most important anthropogenic GHGGreenhouse gas is due to various factors, including: (a) tropospheric O3ozonetropospheric is not emitted directly by humans but rather is produced in the atmosphere following chemical reactions of O3 precursors released by humans; (b) surface O3, which is an important sub-category of tropospheric O3ozonetropospheric, is regulated by air quality agencies throughout the world (i.e., O3 poses more harm to air quality than to climate); (c) all of the other anthropogenic GHGs tend to be long lived (atmospheric lifetimes greater than a year) and have nearly uniform global distributions, whereas tropospheric O3ozonetropospheric is short lived (atmospheric lifetime of minutes to hours) and is highly variable. In the minds of most climate scientists, N2Onitrous oxide survives the challenge from tropospheric O3ozonetropospheric to its third place ranking among anthropogenic GHGs.

We conclude this section by noting the radiative forcingradiative forcing of climate due to tropospheric ozone is due mainly to enhancements over background levels in the tropical upper tropospheretroposphere (Shindell and Faluvegi 2009). Elevated levels of ozone in this region of the atmosphere are mainly due to biomass burningaerosolsbiomass burning (Anderson et al. 2016). It is therefore likely that air quality regulations in the developed world will have little effect on the RF ofradiative forcing climate due to tropospheric O3ozonetropospheric, since so much of the developed world is outside of the tropics. Reducing human set fires in the tropics is a vexing problem, given that many of the fires are set to clear land for agricultureagriculture. Nonetheless, the development of effective controls on human set fires will likely be necessary to reduce the RF ofradiative forcing climate due to tropospheric O3ozonetropospheric (Keywood et al. 2013).

sec.title: HFCs, PFCs, SF6 and NF3
sec.p: Sulfur hexafluoride (SF6minor GHGssulfur hexafluoride) and the class of compounds called hydrofluorocarbons (HFCsminor GHGshydrofluorocarbons) and perfluorocarbons (PFCsminor GHGsperfluorocarbons) often appear in the climate regulation lexicon because these compounds, along with CO2carbon dioxide, CH4methane, and N2Onitrous oxide, were all considered by the original KyotoKyoto Protocol Protocol. Over the course of the AnthropoceneAnthropocene, it is estimated that the RF ofradiative forcing climate due to SF6minor GHGssulfur hexafluoride, HFCsminor GHGshydrofluorocarbons, and PFCsminor GHGsperfluorocarbons has been about 0.03 W m−2 (Other F-gases, Fig. 1.4), which is about 1 % of the total RF ofradiative forcing climate due to all anthropogenic GHGs. Nonetheless, there is concern the RF ofradiative forcing climate of these compounds could rise in the future (IPCC/TEAP 2005; Velders et al. 2009; Zhang et al. 2011). The Doha amendment, adopted in December 2012, added nitrogen trifluoride (NF3) to the list of GHGs in the KyotoKyoto Protocol Protocol. As such, we’ll provide a brief description of the lifetimes, GWPglobal warming potential, and industrial uses of HFCsminor GHGshydrofluorocarbons, PFCsminor GHGsperfluorocarbons, SF6minor GHGssulfur hexafluoride, and NF3.

First a little demystification of the chemistry. All of the compounds considered in this section contain at least one fluorine (F) atom, which is in the halogen column of the periodic table. Also and most importantly, none of the compounds discussed here contain any chlorine or bromine atoms. Chlorine (Cl) and bromine (Br), two other halogens, are harmful to Earth’s ozone layer and any industrial compound containing either Cl or Br that has a long enough lifetime to reach the stratospherestratosphere falls under the auspices of the Montreal ProtocolMontreal Protocol. Natural production of HFCsminor GHGshydrofluorocarbons, PFCsminor GHGsperfluorocarbons, SF6minor GHGssulfur hexafluoride and NF3 does not occur. Therefore, the presence of these compounds in the atmosphere at a detectable level is attributed to human activity.

The HFCsminor GHGshydrofluorocarbons, PFCsminor GHGsperfluorocarbons, SF6minor GHGssulfur hexafluoride and NF3 group of GHGs are chemically stable and radiatively active. Most of these compounds have either a single central element surrounded by either numerous fluorine atoms or some combination of fluorine and hydrogen atoms, or a central double carbon similarly surrounded. These chemicals have various physical properties that have resulted in a wide range of industrial applications. The molecular structure of these compounds makes them very long lived: most survive intact until they encounter the intense ultraviolet radiationradiationultraviolet radiation environment of Earth’s upper stratospherestratosphere, except for some HFCsminor GHGshydrofluorocarbons that are removed by chemical reactions in Earth’s tropospheretroposphere. Finally, the presence of F in these molecules creates what scientists call a strong dipole moment. These dipole moments tend to occur at wavelengths where thermal radiationradiationinfrared radiation emitted by Earth’s surface would otherwise escape to space (i.e., an atmospheric window). Chemicals that are long-lived and absorb in an atmospheric window tend to have large GWPsglobal warming potential. Typically, the more F in a compound, the higher the GWPglobal warming potential (Bera et al. 2009).

Table 1.2 gives the GWPsglobal warming potential (100-year time horizon), atmospheric lifetimes, and industrial uses of HFCsminor GHGshydrofluorocarbons, PFCsminor GHGsperfluorocarbons, SF6minor GHGssulfur hexafluoride, and NF3. The information is based on Table 8.A.1 of IPCC (2013) and is intended to serve as a synopsis of this longer table, which spans four pages, covers more than 100 compounds, and contains many properties for each compound. Only ranges of GWPsglobal warming potential and lifetimes are given for HFCsminor GHGshydrofluorocarbons and PFCsminor GHGsperfluorocarbons in Table 1.2. The atmospheric lifetime for some of these molecules is remarkably long (CF4, a PFC, has a lifetime of 50,000 years) and many of the GWPsglobal warming potential are huge (C2F6, another PFC, has a GWPglobal warming potential of 11,100).Table 1.2
